User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8) AppleWebKit/535.8 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/17.0.928.0 Safari/535.8

Steps to reproduce:

Since Mozilla 8.0 the unified toolbar is rendered underneath the main content of the window. This problem can be easily demonstrated by doing the following:

1. create a toolbar
2. create box with box shadow and with flex set to 1

When the application is opened under mozilla 8.0, the shadow of the box is rendered on the top of the toolbar. In mozilla 6.0 the box shadow of the flex box does not go over the toolbar, i.e. the correct behaviour.

This affects Firefox 8.


Actual results:

Please see the attached sample application which demonstrates the problem.

comments.text:
I'm surprised that this doesn't happen in mozilla 6.

I think the new behavior is the correct one, even if it's not the right one for your use case. Elements that come later in the DOM are usually placed on top of earlier elements (including their shadow), unless there are CSS rules that change this.

See http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visuren.html#layers

The easiest solution for your case would be to give the toolbar position:relative. This makes the toolbar a "positioned descendant" of #main-content-vbox and is thus painted in group 7 (see the spec), on top of the vbox below which is a normal in-flow non-positioned descendant and painted in group 3.
